DOC.HEAD: Soviet Miners to Visit; Solidarity-like Support Promised
DOC.TEXT: The AFL-CIO says it will host a nearly month-long visit to the United States by 10 Soviet miners seeking to form independent unions and promises to support the miners even if it has to defy the Soviet government. Lane Kirkland, president of the 14.1 million-member labor federation, announced Tuesday that the delegation would arrive in the United States on Dec. 29 for a nearly month-long stay. The visit will begin in New York and bring the miners to Washington on Jan. 3. A more detailed itinerary was not available, but the delegation plans to visit some U.S. mines to study mining and safety practices, Kirkland said. The miners will be the guests of the AFL-CIO but their trip is being paid for by through a U.S. Information Agency exchange program. The AFL-CIO has repeatedly refused torecognize visits by members of government-sanctioned Soviet unions, arguing those are little more than puppet organizations. The miners requested the AFL-CIO's support last month and Kirkland, likening their struggle to that of Solidarity organizers in Poland in the early 1980s, promised American unions would deliver. ``If necessary,'' was Kirkland's response when asked if the AFL-CIO would take the same steps it took to support Solidarity, which included the smuggling of printing and other communications equipment into Poland during the period in which Solidarity was outlawed. In all, the federation gave about $5 million worth of equipment and other assistance to Solidarity. Although it refused to allow the federation delegation into the Soviet Union, Kirkland noted that the Soviet government had allowed two trade union activists to attend the AFL-CIO's recent convention and had granted exit visas to the miners, all members of strike committees which have been at loggerheads with the Kremlin. Because of those steps, Kirkland said it was clear ``there is a measure of glasnost'' in Kremlin policy toward independent union activity and said that made it unclear whether the Soviet government would move to block AFL-CIO support of the miners. ``I'm interested in testing its limits,'' Kirkland said of the Soviet government. The Soviet miners scheduled to visit were among the leaders of strikes by thousands of Soviet miners beginning last summer. Soviet leader Mikhail S. Gorbachev was critical of the strikers, accusing them of undermining his efforts to revive the Soviet economy.
